column17: INTERCALIBRATION OF MEASUREMENTS FROM MICROWAVE SENSORS FOR TROPICAL RAINFALL MEASURING MISSION (TRMM)  THIS WORK WHICH WILL UTILIZE A RANGE OF MICROWAVE AND INFRARED MEASUREMENTS IN CLEAR-SKY CONDITIONS, WILL ENABLE ACCURATE INTERCALIBRATION ACROSS THE FULL RANGE OF FREQUENCIES TO BE MEASURED BY THE TRMM MICROWAVE IMAGER (TMI) TMI AND GLOBAL PRECIPITATION MEASUREMENT (GPM) MICROWAVE IMAGER (GMI)  INSTRUMENTS.  WE WILL DEVELOP EMPIRICAL SEA SURFACE EMISSIVITY MODELS TO PROVIDE SURFACE TERM ESTIMATES FOR MICROWAVE CHANNELS THAT RECEIVE A SIGNIFICANT SURFACE CONTRIBUTION AND CHECK THE CONSISTENCY OF THESE MODELS FOR DIFFERENT INSTRUMENTS.

column9: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization
column17: Making the best use of Sea Surface Salinity (SSS) data from the Aquarius instrument will require a comprehensive understanding of the skin properties measured by Aquarius, the upper ocean SSS distributions, and the freshwater fluxes across the air-sea interface.  A complex Aquarius calibration/validation effort is being planned using available and new in situ records, but issues of collocation in time and depth and mismatch in spatial coverage will present significant challenges.  This proposal complements the calibration/validation efforts with a modeling component to help determine the expected variations of SSS with depth and the amount of short timescale SSS variance that may be present in the upper ocean.  Using as a basis model estimates that are constrained to most available ocean observations, including in situ salinity, but have relatively thick (10 m) upper layers, experiments with higher vertical resolutions near the surface will be performed.  Results from runs for the period overlapping the Aquarius mission will be compared to the satellite SSS measurements as well as to the in situ data.  Budget analyses of SSS will help determine the relation between Aquarius data, upper ocean SSS structures, and the air-sea forcing fluxes.  The proposed work will help with the proper interpretation of the SSS satellite retrievals and the determination of appropriate measures of data uncertainty, and will make it easier for the wider community to begin exploiting the Aquarius observations. either for pure data studies or for modeling and assimilation efforts.

column9: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization
column17: IGF::OT::IGF OTHER FUNCTIONS.  VERIFICATION OF SPECTROSCOPEIC INPUT TO THE OCO-2 FORWARD MODEL AND RELATED ERROR CHARACTERIZATION. PROPOSAL TITLE: VERIFICATION OF SPECTROSCOPIC INPUT TO THE OCO-2 FORWARD MODEL AND RELATED ERROR CHARACTERIZATION. IN ORDER TO IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF THE PROCESSES CONTROLLING ATMOSPHERIC C02, OCO-2 OBSERVATIONS WILL REQUIRE PRECISIONS AND ACCURACIES BETTER THAN 0.3 % (-1P PPM) IN ORDER TO CAPTURE THE RELEVANT SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL VARIATIONS. THE ACCURACY OF THE SPECTROSCOPIC INPUT TO THE FORWARD MODEL WILL BE KEY TO MEETING THIS REQUIREMENT. TO ENABLE THE PROVISION OF ADVICE AND INFORMATION TO THE OCO-2 TEAM, WE WILL PERFORM INDEPENDENT VALIDATION OF THE SPECTROSCOPIC INPUT TO THE OCO-L FORWARD MODEL USING COMPARISONS BETWEEN A LINE-BY-LINE RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODEL AND HIGH-QUALITY, SPECTRALLY-RESOLVED, ATMOSPHERIC GROUND-BASED MEASUREMENTS FROM THE TOTAL COLUMN CARBON OBSERVING NETWORK (TCCON), AS WELL AS OTHER GROUND-BASED AND LABORATORY DATASETS. WE WILL USE THE SPECTRAL RESIDUALS FROM THE VALIDATION TO PROVIDE ERROR ESTIMATES FOR THE SPECTROSCOPIC PARAMETERS, WHICH CAN THEN BE USED TO QUANTIFY THE IMPACT OF SPECTROSCOPIC UNCERTAINTIES ON RETRIEVAL ERROR. WE WILL ALSO ASSIST THE OCO-2 TEAM WITH EARLY ASSESSMENT OF DATA QUALITY BY PERFORMING MODEL/MEASUREMENT CALCULATIONS FOR SELECTED OCO-2 OBSERVATIONS. THE PROPOSED WORK WILL PROVIDE INDEPENDENT VERIFICATION OF THE ACCURACY OF THE SPECTROSCOPIC INPUT USED BY THE OCO-L FORWARD MODEL. THE PARTICIPATION OF THE PI AND CO-PI ON THE OC0-2 SCIENCE TEAM WOULD ALSO ALLOW THEM TO HELP PROPAGATE SPECTROSCOPIC ADVANCES LED BY THE OCO-L TEAM TO THE BROADER ATMOSPHERIC SCIENCE COMMUNITY.

column9: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization
column17: IGF::OT::IGF OTHER FUNCTIONS THIS EFFORT IS FOR A CONTINUATION OF NASA GSFC\'S ACTIVITIES RELATED TO THE CARBON MONITORING SYSTEM, FLUX PILOT STUDY (CMS FPP). THE WORK WILL ENHANCE AND DEVELOP THE CAPABILITIES OF NASA\'S GODDARD EARTH OBSERVING SYSTEM (GEOS) SET OF MODELS AND ASSIMILATION COMPONENTS TO FURTHER DEVELOP A CORE CAPABILITY FOR CMS-RELATED CARBON CYCLE SCIENCE AND MONITORING. THE WORK CONSISTS OF THREE COMPONENTS: (I) CONTINUATION OF PAST WORK TO COMPUTE ATMOSPHERE-OCEAN AND ATMOSPHERE-LAND BIOSPHERE FLUXES, AS WELL AS THEIR EVALUATION USING FORWARD MODELING IN GEOS-5; (II) ENHANCEMENTS OF GEOS-5 FOR CARBON MONITORING, INCLUDING A MODEL STUDY OF THE INTERMINGLING OF UNCERTAINTIES IN ANTHROPOGENIC AND LAND-BIOSPHERIC CARBON EMISSIONS, AND DEVELOPMENT OF AN ENHANCED ASSIMILATION CAPABILITY TO INCLUDE MULTIPLE SPACE-BORNE CO2 ESTIMATES (FROM AIRS AND ACOS-GOSAT); (III) A FOCUSED ACTIVITY THAT EXAMINES ASPECTS RELATED TO TOP-DOWN (INVERSE) ESTIMATES OF CARBON FLUXES. THE LATTER EFFORT WILL INCLUDE A CONTROLLED COMPARISON OF THREE INVERSE ESTIMATES, INCLUDING THE ONE FROM CMS FPP, THAT USE THE SAME INPUT DATA BUT USE DIFFERENT METHODS. IT ALSO INCLUDES THE IMPLEMENTATION AND APPLICATION OF A LAGRANGIAN PARTICLE DISPERSION MODEL TO COMPUTE GLOBAL FOOTPRINTS OF GOSAT OBSERVATIONS. FURTHER, SUBSTANTIAL NEW DEVELOPMENTS WILL BE IMPLEMENTED INTO AN EXISTING VARIATION INVERSION SYSTEM. THE WORK PROPOSED IN GEOS-CARB WILL IMPLEMENT AND ADAPT VARIOUS MODELING AND ANALYSIS TOOLS, LINKING THEM CLOSELY WITH GEOS-5 SYSTEMS AVAILABLE IN THE GLOBAL MODELING AND ASSIMILATION OFFICE, IN ORDER TO BETTER EXPLOIT NASA S CARBON-RELEVANT OBSERVATIONS FOR MONITORING AND UNDERSTANDING THE GLOBAL CARBON CYCLE. THE DEVELOPMENT WORK WILL LEAVE NASA WITH ENHANCED MODELING AND ANALYSIS TOOLS FOR CARBON-CYCLE MONITORING USING SPACE-BASED OBSERVATIONS. THESE TOOLS WILL BE USED TO ADDRESS SOME OF THE RESEARCH QUESTIONS THAT HAVE ARISEN IN THE COURSE OF CMS FPP, WITH A STRONG EMPHASIS ON CHARACTERIZING UNCERTAINTY IN CO2 FLUX COMPUTATIONS.

column9: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization
column17: IGF::OT::IGF  THIS CONTRACT IS FOR THE DEVELOPMENT, TESTING, AND IMPLEMENTATION METHODS FOR DOWNSCALING LOW-RESOLUTION FLOOD FRACTION ESTIMATES FROM MICROWAVE SENSORS TO CREATE HIGH-RESOLUTION MAPS OF INUNDATION GLOBALLY.  FLOODED FRACTION MEASURES LOCAL TERRESTRIAL SURGACE WATER COVER, WHICH IS A CRITICAL VARIABLE IN GLOBAL HYDROLOGIVAL AND BIOCHEMICAL CYCLES, ECOLOGY, AGRICULTURE, FRESH WATER SUPPLY, AND POLLUTANT DISPERSION.  GLOBALLY, SURFACE WATER COVER CHANGES CONTINUOUSLY WITH SIGNIFICANT DAILY, SEASONAL, AND INTER-ANNUAL VARIATIONS, AND YET CURRENT REMOTE SENSING METHODS ARE INCAPABLE OF MAKING THE FREQUENT, HIGH-RESOLUTION MAPS OF OPEN WATER AND VEGETATED WETLANDS NEEDED TO ADEQUATELY MONITOR THESE CHANGES.  THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE CURRENT MEASURED GAP BY LEVERAGING MICROWAVE MEASUREMENTS, WHICH ARE LOW-RESISTANT BUT PENETRATE CLOUD COVER AND HAVE BEEN AVAILABLE FOR MORE THAN TWO DECADES WITH AT LEAST DAILY GLOBAL COVERAGE.  STATISTICAL, PHYSICAL, AND HYRID DOWNSCALING METHODS WILL BE DEVELOPOED AND TESTED USING HIGH-RESOLUTION IMAGERY OF UNNUNDATION EXTENT FROM SYNTHETIC APERTURE RADAR AND VISIBLE/NEAR-INFRARED SATELLITE IMAGERY.  THE METHODS WILL BE APPLIED OVER A ONE-YEAR DEMONSTRATION PERIOD TO (1) AN EXISTING GLOBAL DATASET OF FLOODED FRACTION DERIVED FROM MULTIPLE SATELLITE SENSORS AT 10 DAY INTERVALS AND (2) A NEW FLOODED FRACTION DATASET TO BE DERIVED TWICE-DAILY FROM ADVANCED MICROWAVE SCANNING RADIOMETER FOR EOS DATA.  IN ADDITION TO DOWNSCALING METHOD DEVELOPMENT, THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL ADDRESS PRIMARY OBJECTIVES IN TWO AREAS.  FIRST, ASSESS THE POTENTIAL APPLICATIONS OF THE INNUNDATION DATASETS IN CLIMATE, ECOLOGY, AND FLOOD HAZARD STUDIES.  SECOND, DATASETS TO BE DERIVED WILL BE USEFUL AS TEST BEDS FOR TWO FUTURE NASA MISSIONS.

column9: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization
column17: IGF::OT::IGF  NRA AWARD FOR THE FOLLWOWING RESEARCH: IN THIS PROJECT, THE CONTRACTOR WILL ESTABLISH THE CAPABILITY FOR ACCURACY PARAMETERIZING SOLAR VARIABILITY INTO THE RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODEL, THE OPERATIONAL SHORTWAVE RADIATION CODE IN NUMEROUS CLIMATE PREDICTION MODELS, INCLUDING THE UPCOMING V5 OF THE WHOLE ATMOSPHERE COMMUNITY CLIMATE MODEL (WACCM), WHICH IS A WIDELY-USED MODEL FOR THE STUDY OF SOLAR CYCLE IMPACTS ON CLIMATE.  THE CONTRACTOR WILL INTRODUCE TWO SPECIFICATIONS OF SOLAR VARIABILITY INTO THE RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODEL, AS WELL AS ALLOW THE CODE TO HANDLE A USER S ARBITRARY SPECIFICATION OF THE SPECTRAL VARIABILITY OF SOLAR IRRADIANCE.  THESE IMPROVEMENTS WILL TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THE INTERNAL SPECTRAL RESOLUTION OF THE RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODEL, WHICH IS NEEDED TO ACCURATELY PARAMETERIZE SOLAR VARIABILITY EFFECTS, IN CONTRAST TO ALTERNATE APPROACHES THAT MERELY SCALE INDIVIDUAL SPECTRAL BANDS IN THE CODE.  THESE CHANGES WILL BE VALIDATED AGAINST CORRESPONDING CALCULATIONS BY LINE-BY-LINE RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODELS FOR A NUMBER OF KEY TEST ATMOSPHERES.  THE IMPROVED MODEL WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO VERSION 5 OF WACCM AND A SERIES OF SIMULATIONS WILL BE PERFORMED TO QUANTIFY THE DEGREE TO WHICH MODEL PREDICTIONS IMPROVE WHEN THE RADIATIVE IMPACTS OF SOLAR VARIABILITY ARE PROPERLY ACCOUNTED FOR AND TO ENHANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPACTS OF THE INTRA-SPECTRAL SOLAR VARIABILITY ON SURFACE CLIMATE.  BY IMPROVING THE ABILITY OF THE RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODEL TO ACCOUNT FOR THE RADIATIVE IMPACT OF SOLAR VARIABILITY, THE PROPOSED WORK WILL ALLOW THE IMPROVEMENT OF THE UNDERSTANDING OF HOW AND TO WHAT DEGREE VARIATIONS IN THE SOLAR RADIATIVE OUTPUT CONTRIBUTE TO CHANGES IN GLOBAL AND REGIONAL CLIMATE OVER A WIDE RANGE OF TIME SCALES, A KEY STRATEGIC GOAL OF THE NASA LIVING WITH A STAR PROGRAM.  IN ADDITION, THE PLANNED RADIATION CODE IMPROVEMENTS AND SUBSEQUENT WACCM MODELING EXPERIMENTS WILL ALLOW ADVANCE OF THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE COUPLING OF THE UPPER AND LOWER ATMOSPHERE AND THE PROCESSES RESPONSIBLE FOR TRANSMITTING SOLAR VARIATIONS TO THE EARTH S SURFACE WHERE THEY CAN MODULATE GLOBAL AND REGIONAL CLIMATE.  THE RADIATION CODE DEVELOPMENT WORK PROPOSED IS TARGETED AT EVALUATING THE SPECTRAL DETAIL NECESSARY FOR PROPER TREATMENT OF THE RAIDATIVE AND PHOTOCHEMICAL RESPONSE TO SOLAR SPECTRAL VARIABILITY.

column9: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization
column17: IGF::OT::IGF  RESEARCH EFFORT ENTITLED:  ASSESSING THE RELATIONSHIPS AMONG PRECIPITATION, WATER VAPOR AND SURFACE TEMPERATURE IN MERRA AND THE GISS MODEL E S AMIP5/CMIP5 RUNS USING SATELLITE-BASED MEASUREMENTS.   ATMOSPHERIC RADIATIVE PROCESSES ARE KEY DRIVERS OF THE EARTH S CLIMATE AND MUST BE ACCURATELY REPRESENTED IN GLOBAL CIRCULATIONS MODELS (GCMS) TO ALLOW FAITHFUL SIMULATIONS OF THE PLANET S PAST, PRESENT, AND FUTURE. IN ADDITION, THE SPECTRAL SIGNATURE OF RADIATION EXITING THE ATMOSPHERE CONTAINS DETAILED INFORMATION ABOUT ATMOSPHERIC PROPERTIES AND COMPOSITION, INFORMATION OF CRITICAL IMPORTANCE TO OUR UNDERSTANDING OF NUMEROUS GEOPHYSICAL PROCESSES AND CYCLES. THESE TWO ASPECTS OF RADIATION ARE BOTH ESSENTIAL TO THE OBJECTIVES OF THE GODDARD EARTH OBSERVATION SYSTEM (GEOS), WHICH INCLUDES BOTH A COUPLED ATMOSPHERE-OCEAN GCM THAT REQUIRES AN ACCURATE PARAMETERIZATION OF RADIATIVE FLUXES AND HEATING RATES, AND A DATA ASSIMILATION SYSTEM THAT CAN UTILIZE SPECTRALLY RESOLVED RADIATION MEASUREMENTS FROM A DIVERSE SET OF SATELLITE-BASED INSTRUMENTS. THIS PROPOSAL SUPPORTS BOTH OF THESE GEOS-5 OBJECTIVES BY DEVELOPING AN ENHANCED RADIATION PACKAGE FOR GEOS-5 THAT WILL PROVIDE ACCURATE AND EFFICIENT CALCULATIONS OF RADIATIVE FLUXES, HEATING RATES, AND SATELLITE RADIANCES. A KEY ELEMENT OF THIS RADIATION PACKAGE WILL BE AN IMPROVED VERSION OF AER S RRTMG RADIATION CODE, RECENTLY IMPLEMENTED IN GEOS-5, WHICH WILL BE UPDATED TO BE CONSISTENT WITH CURRENT SPECTROSCOPIC KNOWLEDGE. IN ADDITION, DEFICIENCIES IDENTIFIED IN RRTMG WILL BE RESOLVED AND LONGWAVE SCATTERING CAPABILITY WILL BE ADDED. THE ENHANCED RADIATION PACKAGE WILL ALSO INCLUDE THE CAPABILITY TO COMPUTE SATELLITE RADIANCES FROM INSTRUMENTS IDENTIFIED AS PRIORITIES BY OUR GMAO COLLEAGUES; THIS CODE WILL BE DEVELOPED USING AER S OPTIMAL SPECTRA SAMPLING (OSS) APPROACH, THE FOUNDATION FOR A NEW VERSION OF THE COMMUNITY RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODEL (CRTM), USED FOR DATA ASSIMILATION AT THE JOINT CENTER FOR SATELLITE DATA ASSIMILATION (JCSDA). ALTHOUGH THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THIS PROPOSED RADIATION PACKAGE AND CRTM/OSS WILL PROVIDE CONSISTENCY AND SYNERGY BETWEEN GMAO AND JCSDA EFFORTS, A KEY PRIORITY OF THE PROPOSED WORK WILL BE THE DEVELOPMENT OF OSS-BUILT SATELLITE SIMULATION CODE FOR INSTRUMENTS RELEVANT TO SCIENTIFIC APPLICATIONS OTHER THAN WEATHER. OUR FOCUS IN THIS EFFORT WILL BE SATELLITE CHANNELS THAT PROVIDE INFORMATION ON ATMOSPHERIC COMPOSITION, THEREBY SUPPORTING GEOS-5 DATA ASSIMILATION OF GREENHOUSE GASES (GHG), ATMOSPHERIC CHEMISTRY AND AEROSOLS. THE DEVELOPMENT OF ACCURATE AND EFFICIENT SATELLITE RADIANCE SIMULATION CAPABILITIES FOR GEOS-5 WILL PROVIDE A KEY MECHANISM TO EXPAND OUR ABILITY TO UNDERSTAND THE PROPERTIES AND EVOLUTION OF THE EARTH SYSTEM. THE ENHANCED RADIATION PACKAGE WILL BE EXTREMELY FLEXIBLE, ALLOWING USERS TO CHOOSE THE DESIRED MIXTURE OF AVAILABLE FLUX AND SATELLITE RADIANCE CALCULATIONS FOR THEIR PARTICULAR APPLICATION, THEREBY MINIMIZING THE COMPUTATIONAL COST. THIS DEVELOPMENT WILL SIGNIFICANTLY ENHANCE THE GEOS-5 REPRESENTATION OF RADIATIVE PROCESSES, OF CRITICAL IMPORTANCE ACROSS A WIDE RANGE OF SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALES. THIS WORK WOULD THEREBY SUPPORT THE MAP PROGRAM OBJECTIVE OF ATTAINING A COMPLETE UNDERSTANDING THE EARTH SYSTEM, AS WELL AS ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF GEOS-5 SIMULATIONS AND REANALYSIS PRODUCTS PRODUCED BY THE MODEL. THE ENHANCED RADIATION PACKAGE WOULD ALSO BENEFIT OTHER MAP PROJECTS RELATED TO GEOS-5, SUCH AS THE GLOBAL MODELING INITIATIVE AND THE NASA UNIFIED WEATHER RESEARCH FORECAST MODEL, OTHER MODELING CENTERS (SUCH AS NCAR, NCEP, ECMWF) THAT USE RRTMG OR MAY ELECT TO IMPLEMENT THE SATELLITE RADIANCE SIMULATION CAPABILITY (GISS), AS WELL AS PROVIDING INFRASTRUCTURE TO ASSESS FUTURE SATELLITE INSTRUMENTS.

column9: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization
column17: IGF::OT::IGF PROTOTYPE MONITORING, REPORTING AND VERIFICATION SYSTEM FOR THE REGIONAL SCALE: THE BOSTON-DC CORRIDOR.  THE WORLD S POPULATION GROWTH IS INCREASINGLY CONCENTRATED IN URBAN AREAS AND THIS TREND IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE IN THE FUTURE. URBANIZATION HAS A PROFOUND IMPACT ON CARBON DYNAMICS, LEADING TO INCREASES IN ANTHROPOGENIC CARBON DIOXIDE (CO2) EMISSIONS AND DECREASES IN BIOGENIC FLUXES FROM THESE AREAS. THE LATTER ARE A KEY COMPONENT OF A CARBON MONITORING SYSTEM (CMS), WHILE SPATIALLY AND TEMPORALLY RESOLVED ESTIMATES OF ANTHROPOGENIC FLUXES ARE CENTRAL TO MEETING GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS REDUCTIONS GOALS. WE INTEND TO DESIGN A MEASUREMENT NETWORK AND DEVELOP AN ACCOMPANYING ATMOSPHERIC MODELING FRAMEWORK FOR DOWNSCALING THE CURRENT NASA CMS FLUX PRODUCTS TO THE REGIONAL AND LOCAL SCALES PERTINENT TO MONITORING, REPORTING, AND VERIFICATION (MRV). OUR PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL FOCUS ON THE BOSTON-DC MEGALOPOLIS CORRIDOR, WHERE ABOUT 17% OF THE U.S. POPULATION LIVES ON LESS THAN 2% OF THE NATION S LAND AREA, MAKING IT A KEY SOURCE OF US ANTHROPOGENIC CO2 EMISSIONS. SIMULTANEOUSLY, THESE URBAN AREAS ARE INTERSPERSED WITH VEGETATION THAT IMPOSES A STRONG BIOGENIC SIGNAL ON THE ATMOSPHERIC CO2 MIXING RATIOS. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL PROCEED ALONG THREE MAIN LINES: 1) HIGH-RESOLUTION TRANSPORT MODELING (WRF-STILT) CUSTOMIZED AND VERIFIED FOR THE REGION, 2) HIGH-RESOLUTION CO2 FLUX MODEL INCORPORATING ANTHROPOGENIC EMISSIONS ESTIMATES AND THE CASA MODEL (INCLUDING ITS 0.5-DEG RESOLUTION VARIANT THAT PROVIDES THE FOUNDATIONAL BIOSPHERE MODEL FOR THE CURRENT CMS FLUX PRODUCT AND NESTED HIGHER RESOLUTION RUNS TO REPRESENT THE SCALE SENSITIVITY WITHIN HETEROGENEOUS URBAN AREAS), AND 3) INVERSE CO2 FLUX ESTIMATES CORRESPONDING TO IN-SITU AND REMOTE CO2 OBSERVATIONS IN AND AROUND BOSTON, NEW YORK CITY, AND WASHINGTON DC. AS PART OF THE PROPOSED WORK, WE WILL QUANTIFY ERRORS IN THE WRF-STILT SIMULATIONS OF THE PLANETARY BOUNDARY LAYER (PBL), RELYING FOR THIS PURPOSE ON REMOTELY SENSED PBL MEASUREMENTS BY THE SIGMA SPACE CORPORATION S MICRO PULSE LIDAR (MPL). THE PBL HEIGHT IS A KEY PARAMETER ENTERING INVERSE FLUX ESTIMATES, AS IT DETERMINES THE MIXING REGION AND VARIES INVERSELY TO THE TRACE GAS CONCENTRATIONS.  A KEY RESULT OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL BE THE QUANTIFICATION OF OBSERVING REQUIREMENTS FOR FLUX UNCERTAINTY REDUCTION TO LEVELS NEEDED FOR MRV. OUR PROPOSAL ADDRESSES TWO STATED GOALS OF THE NNH13ZDA001N-CMS SOLICITATION:  STUDIES USING COMMERCIAL OFF-THE-SHELF TECHNOLOGIES TO PRODUCE AND EVALUATE PROTOTYPE MRV SYSTEM APPROACHES  AND  STUDIES TO IMPROVE THE CHARACTERIZATION AND QUANTIFICATION OF ERRORS AND UNCERTAINTIES IN EXISTING AND/OR PROPOSED NASA CMS PRODUCTS, INCLUDING ERRORS AND UNCERTAINTIES IN THE ALGORITHMS, MODELS, AND ASSOCIATED METHODOLOGIES UTILIZED IN CREATING THEM.  THE PROPOSED WORK WILL LEVERAGE AND EXTEND THE CURRENT CMS PROJECTS LED BY DRS. ARLYN ANDREWS AND STEVEN PAWSON, WITH WHICH THE LEAD PROPOSING TEAM AT ATMOSPHERIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESEARCH (AER) IS INTIMATELY INVOLVED, AND THE CMS PILOT SURFACE CARBON FLUXES MODELING ANALYSIS.

column9: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization
column17: IGF::OT::IGF THE GLOBAL PRECIPITATION MEASUREMENT (GPM) MISSION WILL RELY ON A CONSTELLATION OF COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND OPERATIONAL SATELLITES ON MULTIPLE LOW EARTH ORBITING (POLAR AND LOW INCLINATION ORBITS) TO OFFER FREQUENT TEMPORAL SAMPLING FOR GLOBAL PRECIPITATION ESTIMATES. AS WE APPROACH THE TARGETED LAUNCH DATE IN EARLY 2014 OF THE GPM  CORE OBSERVATORY , WHICH WILL CARRY AN ADVANCED RADIOMETER/RADAR SYSTEM THAT IS ESSENTIAL FOR THE UNIFICATION OF THE SUITE OF MICROWAVE SENSORS ABOARD THE GPM CONSTELLATION, MEMBER AGENCIES OF THE JOINT CENTER OF SATELLITE DATA ASSIMILATION (JCSDA) ARE PREPARING TO ASSIMILATE PRECIPITATION AFFECTED MEASUREMENTS FROM GPM INSTRUMENTS INTO NUMERICAL WEATHER PREDICTION (NWP) MODELS TO IMPROVE CLOUD/PRECIPITATION FORECASTING CAPABILITIES.IN RESPONSE TO THIS SOLICITATION, THE CONTRACTOR WILL 1) EVALUATE AND REFINE AN OBSERVATION OPERATOR BASED ON THE JCSDA COMMUNITY RADIATIVE TRANSFER MODEL (CRTM) FOR USE IN THE ASSIMILATION OF PRECIPITATION-AFFECTED RADIANCES (AND PRECIPITATION PRODUCTS) FROM THE GPM SENSORS, USING REAL DATA FROM CURRENT ORBITING IMAGING AND SOUNDING INSTRUMENTS (E.G., TMI, AMSU) AND 2) PERFORM A PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENT OF THE QUALITY OF THE NWP FORECAST FIELDS USED AS BACKGROUND IN THE ASSIMILATION PROCESS. THE RESULTS OF THIS ANALYSIS ARE IMPORTANT IN PARTICULAR FOR THE QUALITY CONTROL OF THE INCOMING OBSERVATIONS AND FOR ASSESSING FORECASTS BACKGROUND AND FORWARD MODEL ERROR STATISTICS. IN THIS ANALYSIS DETAILED PROFILE INFORMATION FROM RADAR MEASUREMENTS WILL BE USED AS OUR MAIN REFERENCE. VALIDATION WILL BE DONE IN A 1DVAR OPTIMAL ESTIMATION FRAMEWORK RELYING ON APPROACHES PREVIOUSLY DEVELOPED BY THE TRMM SCIENCE TEAM TO ALLOW US TO ADJUST MISSING (OR UNCERTAIN) GEOPHYSICAL VARIABLE ESTIMATES WITHIN CONSTRAINTS DERIVED FROM CLIMATOLOGY AND LOCAL ENSEMBLE RUNS FROM REGIONAL MODELS. IN PARTICULAR, WE WILL TEST DIFFERENT OPTICAL PROPERTY TABLES USED IN RADIATIVE TRANSFER CALCULATIONS TO TRANSLATE PRECIPITATION PROFILES PRODUCED BY THE FORECAST MODEL INTO RADIANCES AND ASSESS THE IMPACT OF ASSUMED OPTICAL PROPERTIES ON THE SKILLS OF THE OBSERVATION OPERATOR. IN FUTURE OPERATIONS, IT IS ALSO CRITICAL TO ENSURE THAT THE VARIOUS SENSORS IN THE CONSTELLATION PROVIDE CONSISTENT INFORMATION. BIAS CORRECTION SCHEMES EMPLOYED IN ASSIMILATION ARE DESIGNED TO EFFECTIVELY  CALIBRATE  THE SENSORS USING A COMMON REFERENCE (I.E., THE FORECAST MODEL FIELDS). IN THE CLEAR-SKY, WE TRADITIONALLY OPERATE UNDER THE ASSUMPTION OF HORIZONTAL HOMOGENEITY (PLANE PARALLEL ASSUMPTION) AND IT IS ASSUMED THAT DEPENDENCE OF RADIANCES ON VIEWING ANGLE IS ENTIRELY EXPLAINED BY VARIATIONS IN ATMOSPHERIC PATH. THE AVAILABILITY OF COINCIDENT INFORMATION FROM SENSORS ON DIFFERENT ORBITS WILL ALLOW US TO ASSESS HOW FINE-SCALES CLOUD STRUCTURE IMPACTS MEASUREMENTS MADE UNDER DIFFERENT VIEWING CONDITIONS.FOR THIS EFFORT, THE TARGET IS THE NAVY S GLOBAL NAVGEM MODEL BUT MANY ASPECTS OF THIS WORK ARE GENERIC AND APPLY TO OTHER NWP MODELS AS WELL. RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL ALSO BE REFLECTED IN FUTURE VERSIONS OF THE CRTM AND THUS WILL BENEFIT THE BROADER USER-COMMUNITY. THE PROPOSED PREPARATORY WORK IS PARTICULARLY RESPONSIVE TO THE INTERESTS OF THE JCSDA AND NRL IN PARTICULAR IN ASSIMILATING CLOUDY DATA FROM FUTURE GPM SATELLITE CONSTELLATION AND, AS SUCH, DIRECTLY ADDRESSES THE JCSDA S GOAL  TO ACCELERATE THE ABILITIES OF NOAA, DOD AND NASA TO INGEST DATA FROM CURRENT AND PLANNED SATELLITE MISSION AS WELL AS NASA BROADER LONG-TERM OBJECTIVES UNDER NASA NRA A.33 (DATA FOR OPERATION AND ASSESSMENT)  TO USE GLOBAL MEASUREMENTS TO UNDERSTAND THE EARTH SYSTEMS AND ITS INTERACTIONS AS STEPS TOWARD ULTIMATELY ENABLING PREDICTION OF EARTH BEHAVIOR .

column9: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization
column17: IGF::OT::IGF THIS EFFORT IS TO TEST AN \OCEAN RAIN GAUGE CONCEPT\" AND TO DERIVE PRACTICAL METHODOLOGIES ON HOW TO USE AQUARIUS MEASUREMENTS OF SURFACE SALINITY AND OTHER SATELLITE DATA TO INFER MEANINGFUL VALUES FOR FRESHWATER FLUX. THE TEAM (PI AND CO-I BOTH FROM AER) INCLUDES A JPL COLLABORATOR, AND HAS STRONG SKILLS IN ECCO MODELING AND ANALYSIS AND AQUARIUS SSS. FLUXES OF FRESHWATER OVER THE OCEAN ARE A KEY VARIABLE IN UNDERSTANDING THE GLOBAL HYDROLOGICAL CYCLE. HOWEVER, DESPITE A NUMBER OF RECENT EFFORTS, MAJOR UNCERTAINTIES REMAIN IN THEIR PRESENT-DAY ESTIMATES.  TO IMPROVE KNOWLEDGE OF THESE FLUXES, WE PROPOSE TO TEST A SO-CALLED \"OCEAN RAIN GAUGE CONCEPT\" AND TO DERIVE PRACTICAL METHODOLOGIES ON HOW TO USE AQUARIUS MEASUREMENTS OF SURFACE SALINITY (AND POSSIBLY OTHER SATELLITE DATA) TO INFER MEANINGFUL VALUES FOR FRESHWATER FLUX, FOCUSING ON THE TROPICAL OCEANS AND ON TIME SCALES FROM MONTHS TO DECADES.  THE APPROACH IS TO EXAMINE HOW FRESHWATER FLUXES CAN BE EXPRESSED AS A COMBINATION OF OCEAN VARIABLES BASED ON A MIXED-LAYER SALINITY BUDGET, COMPUTED WITHIN DYNAMICALLY-CONSISTENT, CONSTRAINED ESTIMATIONS OF THE OCEANIC STATE; AND TO USE THIS INFORMATION TO GUIDE THE INFERENCE OF FRESHWATER FLUX VALUES USING A PURE OBSERVATIONAL APPROACH.  A RELATED ISSUE IS KNOWLEDGE OF THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE SATELLITE OBSERVATIONS AND OTHER MEASURES OF NEAR-SURFACE SALINITY.  WE PROPOSE TO CHARACTERIZE THE EXPECTED SALINITY VARIABILITY WITH DEPTH IN THE UPPER OCEAN AS A FUNCTION OF LOCATION AND TIMESCALE, AND TO QUANTIFY AQUARIUS UNCERTAINTIES IN THE CONTEXT OF NEAR-SURFACE SALINITY GRADIENTS.  THE WORK WILL ALSO PROVIDE ESTIMATES OF THE OVERALL AQUARIUS SALINITY ERRORS FOR PROPER ASSIMILATION OF AQUARIUS DATA INTO CLIMATE MODELS, AND WILL ASSESS IMPACT OF AQUARIUS DATA ASSIMILATION ON OCEAN CIRCULATION AND FRESHWATER FLUX ESTIMATES.  EXPANDING OUR KNOWLEDGE OF FRESHWATER FLUXES, QUANTIFYING UNCERTAINTIES IN AQUARIUS MEASUREMENTS, AND IMPROVING CLIMATE MODELS USING OBSERVATIONS FROM NASA SATELLITE MISSIONS ADDRESS CENTRAL SCIENCE QUESTIONS POSED BY NASA''S SCIENCE MISSION DIRECTORATE 2010 SCIENCE PLAN, AS WELL AS THE 2011 NASA STRATEGIC PLAN, SCIENCE GOAL 2.1.  THE PROPOSAL ALSO ADDRESSES A KEY ELEMENT IN THE MISSION CALIBRATION/VALIDATION EFFORTS AND MANY OF THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PRESENT OSST SOLICITATION, INCLUDING THE NEED TO \"USE AQUARIUS DATA IN A FUNDAMENTAL WAY TO FURTHER OCEAN SCIENCE\" AND TO \"ADDRESS SOURCE OF ERRORS AND NOISE IN THE AQUARIUS DATA\"."

column9: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization
column17: IGF::OT::IGF THE OVERARCHING OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO USE NASA''S UNIQUE REMOTE SENSING CAPABILITIES, OBSERVATIONAL DATASETS, AND ANLYSIS AND MODELING TOOLS FOR THE QUANTIFICATION AND PROCESS-BASED UNDERSTANDING OF SPATIOTEMPORAL GRADIENTS IN THE PLANETARY BOUNDARY LAYER HEIGHT IN THE WASHINGTON, D.C.--BALTIMORE AREA DURING THE PERIOD 2001 TO PRESENT.   PROJECT TITLE: UNDERSTANDING SPATIOTEMPORAL VARIABILITY IN URBAN MIXED LAYER HEIGHTS THROUGH OBSERVATIONS AND MODELING

column9: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization
column17: IGF::OT::IGF NASA RESEARCH ANNOUNCEMENT AWARD FOR PROPOSAL ENTITLED:  DATA SERVICES UPGRADE:  ENABLING HELIOPHYSICS CLIMATOLOGY RESEARCH WITH IMPROVED POES/METOP PARTICLE DATA TO THE NASA HEADQUARTERS HELIOPHYSICS INFRASTRUCTURE AND DATA ENVIRONMENT ENHANCEMENTS PROGRAM. WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP AN IMPROVED VERSION OF THE POES/METOP SPACE PARTICLE DATA FOR USE IN HELIOPHYSICS CLIMATOLOGY RESEARCH. WE WILL USE SPECTRAL INVERSION TECHNIQUES DEVELOPED FOR THE AE9/AP9 TRAPPED PARTICLE MODELS TO DERIVE UNIDIRECTIONAL, DIFFERENTIAL PARTICLE FLUXES FROM THE INTEGRAL CHANNELS OF THE POES/METOP SEM-2 MEPED INSTRUMENT. WE WILL ALSO APPLY DATA CLEANING TECHNIQUES TO ENSURE THAT THE RESULTING DATA ARE FREE FROM CONTAMINATION AND OTHER ARTIFACTS OF THE DETECTORS. THE RESULTING DATA SET WILL REPRESENT A SIGNIFICANT IMPROVEMENT IN THE QUALITY AND USEFULNESS OF THE POES/METOP DATA. THE DATA WILL BE DELIVERED IN CDF FORMAT TO NGDC. THE DATA WILL ENABLE NEW ADVANCES IN OUR UNDERSTANDING OF PHENOMENA SUCH AS HIGH ENERGY PARTICLE PRECIPITATION IN THE ATMOSPHERE (HEPPA) AND THE DYNAMICS OF THE EARTH S TRAPPED RADIATION BELTS.

column9: Other Than Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization
column17: Atmospheric and Environmental Research, Inc.  Toward Assimilation of Satellite Data in Modeling Water Vapor Fluxes over Land  This project applies microwave and infrared satellite data to improve model estimations of evaporation over land. These satellite data contain information about near-surface soil and vegetative moisture. The relationships of the measurements to the fluxes is indirect, so analysis of fluxes depends on mathematical or statistical models, which integrate information from other sources. For fluxes over global land areas, bulk formulations for the fluxes are problematic because there are essential parameters for which reliable information is not available, and because the results are highly sensitive to errors in these parameters and to errors in the satellite-provided variables. Data assimilation systems are an attractive option because they have the potential to optimally account for the information content and the error characteristics of all the data sources, while introducing physical constraints with a numerical model. Successful assimilation requires that the model parameterizations and variables are compatible with the satellite measurement sensitivities. When they are incompatible, the satellite information is effectively rejected or misguides the analysis. In this project, we will identify environments and regions where current land surface models are inconsistent with satellite-derived parameters related to evaporation, and hence where modeled evaporative fluxes are likely to be erroneous. This identification will be done employing simple physical and statistical models of expected relationships. For selected environments where inconsistencies are prominent, we will characterize the discrepancies by performing detailed analyses of model variables and satellite and in-situ measurements. The analyses will focus on the surface transfer processes for moisture and energy, and remote sensing phenomenology. The results are intended to provide direction toward improving surface models and their assimilation of data for water vapor flux modeling. This improvement is an essential step toward monitoring and predicting variability of water and energy cycles as manifestations of global change.

column17: THE OVERARCHING OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS THE APPLICATION OF THE WEATHER RESEARCH AND FORECASTING-STOCHASTIC TIME INVERTED LAGRANGIAN TRANSPORT (WRF-STILT) MODEL TO CALCULATE SURFACE INFLUENCES (FOOTPRINTS) OF SATELLITE CO2 OBSERVATIONS AT HIGH SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL RESOLUTION. THE MAIN PROPOSED TASKS ARE: 1) COUPLING OF THE WRF MODEL TO THE MODERN ERA RETROSPECTIVE-ANALYSIS FOR RESEARCH AND APPLICATIONS (MERRA), A NASA ATMOSPHERIC REANALYSIS FOR THE SATELLITE ERA DEVELOPED AT THE GODDARD GLOBAL MODELING AND ASSIMILATION OFFICE, 2) COMPUTATION OF SURFACE SENSITIVITIES AND THEORETICAL FLUX ERROR REDUCTIONS FOR THE CURRENT AND PLANNED SATELLITE CO2 OBSERVATIONS IN DIVERSE REGIONS (NORTH AMERICA, AMAZON), ACCOUNTING FOR THE VERTICAL SENSITIVITY AND ERROR CHARACTERIZATION OF THE SATELLITE MEASUREMENTS, 3) EXPLORATORY COUPLING OF WRF-STILT FOOTPRINTS TO EXISTING FLUX MODELS, AND 4) CHARACTERIZATION OF THE ABILITY OF THE SATELLITE RETRIEVALS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION ON CO2 FLUXES AT SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALES FINER THAN RESOLVED BY CURRENT GLOBAL MODELS. WRF-STILT IS A LEADING TRANSPORT MODEL FOR REGIONAL TOP-DOWN FLUX ESTIMATES, DEVELOPED AND USED BY A LARGE RESEARCH COMMUNITY WORLDWIDE, AND ITS APPLICATION TO SATELLITE CO2 OBSERVATIONS IS OF CRITICAL IMPORTANCE TO THE ATTAINMENT OF FULL SCIENTIFIC POTENTIAL AT REGIONAL AND LOCAL SCALES FROM THE CURRENT AND PLANNED NASA MISSIONS, INCLUDING TES, AIRS, OCO, AND ASCENDS

column17: IGF::OT::IGF  ADVANCED COMPOSITE MATERIALS PROCESSABLE BY COST-EFFECTIVE MANUFACTURING PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN DEVELOPING LIGHTWEIGHT STRUCTURES FOR FUTURE EXPLORATORY MISSIONS. WITH GROWING DEMAND FOR IMPROVED MISSION PERFORMANCE AND REDUCTIONS VEHICLE MASS, ADVANCES IN POLYMER SYSTEMS WITH EXTREME THERMOMECHANICAL PROPERTIES ARE CRITICAL. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF ATSP INNOVATIONS'' PHASE I WORK WILL BE TO FABRICATE AND TEST LOW COST AROMATIC THERMOSETTING COPOLYESTERS (ATSP): (1) FOR HIGH PERFORMANCE COMPOSITE STRUCTURES FOR HIGH TEMPERATURE APPLICATIONS, (2) WITH HIGH RESISTANCE TO MICROCRACKING AT CRYOGENIC TEMPERATURES FOR USE IN NEXT GENERATION SPACECRAFT MISSIONS. OUR TEAM PARTNER, THE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS AT URBANA-CHAMPAIGN (UIUC) WILL ASSIST ATSP INNOVATIONS TO PERFORM ADVANCED CHARACTERIZATION AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT FOR THIS PROJECT. ATSP INNOVATIONS AND UIUC HAVE DEVELOPED ATSP FOR HIGH PERFORMANCE COMPOSITES THAT ARE STABLE AT HIGH TEMPERATURES AND HAVE AN INTRINSIC RESISTANCE TO MICROCRACKING. THE LIQUID CRYSTALLINITY OF THE POLYMER RESULTS IN A LOCAL MATCHING OF CTE BETWEEN FIBER AND MATRIX YIELDING MINIMAL THERMAL RESIDUAL STRESS IN COMPOSITES AND HIGHER FRACTURE TOUGHNESS THAN CURRENT RESIN SYSTEMS. THESE CAPABILITIES ALLOW THE ATSP TO ADDRESS A WIDE RANGE OF CURRENT AND FUTURE APPLICATIONS (AT BOTH CRYOGENIC AND HIGH TEMPERATURE REGIMES) CRITICAL TO FUTURE NASA MISSIONS. THE SYNTHETIC DEVELOPMENT OF ATSP WAS A MAJOR INNOVATION IN THE FIELD OF POLYMER SCIENCE. ATSP SHOWS EXCELLENT PERFORMANCE AS ADHESIVES, FLAME RESISTANT FOAMS, AND TRIBOLOGICAL WEAR COATINGS. ATSP RESINS POSSESS THE UNIQUE ATTRIBUTE AMONG HIGH TEMPERATURE THERMOSETS OF SOLID-STATE BONDING IN A FULLY CURED STATE TO PRODUCE CHEMICALLY CONTIGUOUS SPECIMENS BY INTERCHAIN TRANSESTERIFICATION REACTION (ITR). THIS MAY OPEN NEW MODES OF FABRICATION WITH RELEVANCE TO NASA MISSIONS AND THE WIDER AEROSPACE INDUSTRY.

column17: IGF::OT::IGF BRAIDED OPEN ARCHITECTURE COMPOSITE STRUCTURES (O-ACS) TRADE STUDY WITH AUBURN UNIVERSITYTHE PRIMARY EMPHASIS OF THIS EFFORT IS TO INVESTIGATE ADVANCED MANUFACTURING TECHNIQUES, CONCEPTS, DEVICES, AND/OR SUBSYSTEMS APPLICABLE TO SPACE FLIGHT AND SPACE LAUNCH VEHICLES.THE CONTRACTOR SHALL CONDUCT RESEARCH INTO ADVANCED MANUFACTURING TECHNIQUES AND INVESTIGATE APPLICABILITY THROUGH ANALYSIS, TEST, AND EVALUATION.CONTRACTOR SHALL UTILIZE THE FOLLOWING WORK BREAKDOWN STRUCTURE (WBS) OR DEVELOP A SUITABLE WBS FOR TRACKING THE EFFORT(S).1.0 MANAGEMENT2.0 DESIGN OF EXPERIMENTS3.0 AEROSPACE APPLICATIONS4.0 TESTING AND EVALUATION5.0 MATERIALS AND LAB EXPENSES6.0 FINAL REPORTCONTRACTOR SHALL SEGREGATE EFFORTS BY SEPARATE TASK DESCRIPTIONS AS SHOWN BELOW. TASK DESCRIPTIONS1.0 BASE TASK DESCRIPTION (PHASE 1): BRAIDED OPEN ARCHITECTURE COMPOSITE STRUCTURES (O-ACS) APPLIED TO TENSION-COMPRESSION STRUTSTHE OBJECTIVE OF THE BASE YEAR IS TO BEGIN THE CONCEPTUAL DEVELOPMENT OF THE O-ACS STRUCTURAL MEMBERS FOR LANDING STRUTS AND STRUCTURAL MEMBERS UNDER AXIAL AND BENDING LOADS. IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF STRUTS, THE CONTRACTOR WILL DETERMINE HOW THE STRENGTH AND STIFFNESS OF O-ACS VARY WITH THE ARCHITECTURE.  THIS WILL REQUIRE NOT ONLY THE DESIGN AND ANALYSIS OF THE BRAIDED STRUTS, BUT ALSO METHODS FOR JOINING THE STRUTS TO BE ABLE TO CARRY AXIAL TENSION AND COMPRESSION, TORSION AND BENDING LOADS.  SPECIFICALLY THE CONTRACTOR WILL:EVALUATE YARN SIZE AND STRUCTURE FOR STIFFNESS AND BRAIDABILITY SPECIFICALLY VARYING THE BRAID STRUCTURE AROUND THE PREPREG TOWS AND INVESTIGATE THE POSSIBLE WAYS OF IMPROVING JOINT STABILITY IN THE O-ACS.MODEL THE MECHANICS OF THE JOINT STRUCTURE.BEGIN THE PROCESS OF VARYING THE OPEN AREA SIZE, THE HELICAL ANGLE, THE SPACING OF AXIALS, THE DIAMETER OF THE OPEN STRUCTURE, AND THE WEAVE PATTERN OF THE STRUCTURE. DESIGN AND ANALYZE METHODS FOR CONNECTING THE STRUTS TO EACH OTHER AND TO THE VEHICLE, WHICH INCLUDES THE DEVELOPMENT OF FINITE ELEMENT MODELS OF THE STRUT AND JOINT TO EVALUATE THEIR RESPONSE TO TYPICAL LAUNCH VEHICLE LOADS.TESTING TO EVALUATE THE RELIABILITY OF THE JOINT DESIGN WHEN SUBJECTED TO STATIC LOADS OF THE TYPE TYPICALLY ENCOUNTERED DURING LAUNCH VEHICLE OPERATION.2.0 OPTION TASK DESCRIPTION (PHASE 2):  STRUT STRENGTH OPTIMIZATION  THE OBJECTIVE OF THE OPTION PERIOD IS TO COMPLETE THE EXPERIMENTAL STUDY OF HOW STRUCTURAL GEOMETRY AFFECTS THE PROPERTIES OF O-ACS STRUTS.  SPECIFICALLY THE CONTRACTOR WILL:CONTINUE THE PROCESS OF VARYING THE OPEN AREA SIZE, THE HELICAL ANGLE, THE SPACING OF AXIALS, THE DIAMETER OF THE OPEN STRUCTURE, AND THE WEAVE PATTERN OF THE STRUCTURE. MANUFACTURE AND TEST STRUCTURES IN A STATISTICALLY SOUND DESIGN TO ENABLE STATISTICAL MODELING AS WELL AS FINITE ELEMENT ANALYSIS (FEA).  INVESTIGATE THE POSSIBILITY OF MAKING A BRAIDABLE PREPREG YARN USING FILAMENT WRAPPING TECHNOLOGY. INVESTIGATE ARCHITECTURES FOR IMPROVEMENTS IN TORSIONAL STRENGTH, BENDING STRENGTH, AXIAL COMPRESSIVE (BUCKLING) AND TENSION LOADING.COMPARE THE OACS PROPERTIES TO THOSE OF STANDARD COMPOSITE HAVING SIMILAR WEIGHTS.EXPAND THE ANALYSIS AND TESTING OF THE STRUTS TO INCLUDE DYNAMIC AND VIBRATORY LOADS.DELIVERABLES1.0 BASE PERIOD TASK (PHASE 1):IMPLEMENTATION PLAN OF PHASE 2 DUE NO LATER THAN OCTOBER 1, 2014TRADE STUDY FINAL REPORT DUE NO LATER THAN NOVEMBER 20, 2014THE TRADE STUDY REPORT ON THE PROPOSED TRADE STUDY WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE NASA MSFC ADVANCED DEVELOPMENT OFFICE (ADO). 2.0 OPTION PERIOD TASK (PHASE 2):FINAL REPORT DUE NO LATER THAN MAY 22, 2015FIRST DEVELOPMENT ARTICLE FOR PROPERTY CHARACTERIZATION DELIVERY ON OR BEFORE MAY 22, 2015

column17: BRINGING GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE EDUCATION TO ALABAMA CLASSROOMS:			          THE AIM OF THE PROPOSAL, BRINGING GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE EDUCATION TO ALABAMA CLASSROOMS, IS TO PRODUCE LEARNING MODULES IN THE VARYING SCIENCE FOCUS AREAS OF GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE AND TO PARTNER WITH THE EXISTING ALABAMA SCIENCE IN MOTION PROGRAM (ASIM) TO EFFECTIVELY '' TRAIN TEACHERS AND EDUCATE STUDENTS IN GRADES 9-12.  ALABAMA SCIENCE IN MOTION IS A FULLY-FUNDED PROGRAM IN WHICH ELEVEN PUBLIC COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES IN ALABAMA SERVICE REGIONS BY PROVIDING RESOURCES TO AREA HIGH SCHOOLS. ASIM IS EQUIPPED WITH THIRTY-THREE VANS WHICH TRAVEL THROUGHOUT THE STATE AND DELIVER HIGH-TECH LABORATORY EQUIPMENT AND ENRICH THE SCIENCE PROGRAMS IN SCHOOLS. IN ADDITION, AS1M HOSTS PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOPS FOR TEACHERS, IMPROVING KNOWLEDGE OF SUBJECT MATTER AND EQUIPMENT USE.  THE OBJECTIVE OF BRINGING GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE EDUCATION TO ALABAMA CLASSROOMS IS FOR AUBURN UNIVERSITY FACULTY MEMBERS TO DEVELOP INTERACTIVE EDUCATION MODULES DESIGNED TO ENGAGE HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS ON THE CHANGES IN THE EARTH''S CLIMATE AND ITS EFFECT ON WEATHER, CARBON CYCLE AND ECOSYSTEMS, WATER AND ENERGY CYCLE, CLIMATE VARIABILITY CHANGE, EARTH SURFACE INTERIOR, AND ATMOSPHERIC COMPOSITION. AS1M WILL HOST PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOPS USING THE MODULES AND WILL PROVIDE THE HANDS-ON LABORATORY EXPERIENCE FOR THE STUDENTS DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR.  BRINGING GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE TO ALABAMA''S CLASSROOMS WILL BEGIN TO FILL THE VOID OF GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE EDUCATION AND AWARENESS IN ALABAMA HIGH SCHOOLS, WHILE ATTRACTING STUDENTS TO STEM DISCIPLINES. THE PROGRAM WILL ENHANCE THE EXISTING HIGH SCHOOL SCIENCE CURRICULUM AND ALLOW STUDENTS AND TEACHERS THE ABILITY TO CONDUCT EXPERIMENTS, ANALYZE DATA AND BETTER UNDERSTAND THE ISSUES ASSOCIATED WITH GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE. THE INITIAL MODULES WILL BE GEARED TOWARDS STUDENTS AND TEACHERS IN GRADES 9-12, ALTHOUGH INDIVIDUAL EXERCISES MAY ALSO BE ADAPTABLE TO HIGHER EDUCATION LEVEL COURSE OF STUDY AND EVENTUALLY INCORPORATED INTO DEVELOPING HIGHER EDUCATION CURRICULUM IN GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE IN THE FUTURE.

column17: We propose to use XMM-Newton and Suzaku observations of Tycho's SNR, Cas A, Kepler's SNR, and W49B, together with accurate new calculations of the necessary atomic data, to diagnose the abundances of Fe-peak elements produced in supernovae, in particular those of Cr, Mn, Co and Ni. The Fe-peak elements are key diagnostics of explosive supernova nucleosynthesis. Key to this work is the generation of the first accurate K-sheU electron-impact excitation data for Cr, Mn, Co and Ni. The excitation data will be calculated using the R-matrix method with both Auger and radiative damping included in the resonant excitation channels. We will also calculate ionization and recombination data for these elements, to be used in non-equilibrium ionization modeling. This will allow us to determine the abundances of these heavy elements, and characterize their ionization ages and temperatures. We expect to see differences in the MnlCr yields for remnants ofthermonuclear (Type Ia) supernovae such as Tycho's SNR and those of core-collapse (Type II) supernovae such as Cas A. Measurements of this ratio will thus help to confirm the Type la classification of KepJer's supernova, and ascertain the uncertain supernova Type ofW49B. We will archive the new atomic data for these elements and make them available to the X-ray astrophysics community.

column9: Educational - 1862 Land Grant College, Educational Institution, Other Not For Profit Organization, State Controlled Institution of Higher Learning
column17: The objective of the proposed work is to conduct a systematic study of magnetic reconnection in the vicinity of the Earth's dayside magnetopause as the interplanetary magnetic field changes direction, including the reconnection at the magnetopause and in the magnetosheath. The investigation will be carried out using our 3-D global hybrid simulation model for the coupled bow shock-magnetosheath-magnetosphere system, in which the fully kinetic ion dynamics is solved in the self-consistent electromagnetic field. The reconnection structure and ion kinetic physics will be understood. This modeling work will be performed also in collaboration with satellite observations. The study will address directly to NASA's Heliophysics Division's goals of understanding the fundamental physical processes of the space environment - from the Sun to the Earth". Specifically, studying the global and kinetic physics of magnetic reconnection, a fundamental plasma process at the magnetopause, will contribute not only to our understanding of the mass/energy transport in the Earth's environment, but also to NASA's future missions such as MMS. The proposed modeling work will also significantly improve the development of 3-D global kinetic model of the magnetosphere."

column17: THE PLASMALAB INSTRUMENT WILL BE USED TO CARRY OUT FUNDAMENTAL PHYSICS EXPERIMENTS USING A DUSTY PLASMA. A DUSTY PLASMA CONSISTS OF PARTICLES OF SOLID MATTER SUSPENDED IN AN IONIZED GAS. IT IS SOMETIMES TERMED A COMPLEX PLASMA. MICRON-SIZE PARTICLES ACQUIRE A LARGE NEGATIVE CHARGE OF TYPICALLY 10,000 ELEMENTARY CHARGES. DUE TO INTER-PARTICLE REPULSION, THESE CHARGED PARTICLES ARRANGE THEMSELVES IN SPACE WITH AN ARRANGEMENT, OR STRUCTURE, THAT HAS SOLID- OR LIQUID-LIKE PROPERTIES, SIMILAR TO A COLLOIDAL CRYSTAL. WITH PARTICLES OF THIS SIZE, GRAVITY IS A DOMINANT FORCE, CAUSING PARTICLES TO SEDIMENT TO A THIN LAYER AT THE BOTTOM OF THE PLASMA. UNDER MICROGRAVITY CONDITIONS, PARTICLES FILL A 3D VOLUME.

column9: Educational - 1862 Land Grant College, Educational Institution, Other Not For Profit Organization, State Controlled Institution of Higher Learning
column17: The primary objective of this proposal is to introduce a simple, versatile, cost-effective device for characterizing dynamic fracture of nanocomposite materials. Of particular interest to the proposed research are polymers reinforced with carbon nanotubes and nanofibers. These nanocomposites have shown great potential as structural materials and adhesives under static loading conditions. However, knowing the quasi-static fracture and failure properties of aerospace materials is typically insufficient, as most materials become more brittle at high-strain rate and/or cryogenic temperatures. Additionally, aerospace structures often encounter dynamic transient loading events ranging from tool drop to space debris impact. The destructive capability of seemingly harmless foam traveling at high speeds and cold temperatures was demonstrated tragically in 2003 with the Columbia space shuttle. An understanding of the dynamic failure behavior of aerospace materials is therefore critical for structural safety. The proposed experimental methods can be utilized to accurately determine dynamic crack initiation toughness (Kcr), as well as dynamic fracture toughness as a function of crack growth parameters such as velocity and acceleration. The current setup is designed for testing relatively small samples (1##x1##), but the methodology can easily be scaled down to characterize even smaller specimens. Optically measured stress intensity factors for isotropic acrylic samples have been verified with a computational model. A linear relationship has also been found between pressure input and stress output from the device, allowing for dynamic material characterization over a broad range of strain rates. By altering the material of the pulse shaper and/or striker, an even wider array of strain rates has been attained. The final objective is to demonstrate the effectiveness of this device for measuring fracture parameters of novel anisotropic materials, including orthotropic nanocomposites and adhesives employed in joining dissimilar materials. A gas-gun has been constructed that delivers a one-point impact to a relatively small sample in a controlled fashion. The gas gun launches a cylindrical striker into the long incident bar, sending a stress pulse along the incident bar and into the specimen. Ultra-high-speed digital photography of pre-notched acrylic samples tested on the apparatus show that fracture occurs over a few microseconds, whereas the sample##s motion is perceived in the millisecond time scale (due to inertial effects). Therefore, no additional supports are necessary to insure that crack initiation and propagation occur within the field-of-view of the camera. Using Digital Image Correlation (DIC) method, images collected at #tilde#300,000 frames/sec are compared to those recorded in the undeformed state in order to map deformations in the region of interest. These displacement fields are used to extract fracture parameters, including fracture toughness, stress intensity factors, and crack velocity. Strain gages on the incident bar can then be used to independently verify optically measured stress intensity factors using finite element analysis. The device is designed to cost-effectively test the dynamic fracture properties of materials, both at crack initiation and during crack propagation. Test results will describe not only the initial toughness of the material, but also its ability to resist further crack growth once crack propagation has begun. The apparatus was created for the dynamic fracture testing of newly engineered materials which are expensive to produce in traditional specimen sizes. This methodology is also ideal for testing biomaterials such as bone and bone cement, which are difficult to procure in large sizes. This simple device is inexpensive to construct. By scaling down these methods, current camera technology will allow the future testing of significantly smaller samples, thereby decreasing development costs.

column9: Educational - 1862 Land Grant College, Educational Institution, Other Not For Profit Organization, State Controlled Institution of Higher Learning
column17: Climate change is one of the most urgent issues faced by our nation and the entire world. Recently evidence for global warming has become increasingly difficult to refute, with numerous surveys showing clear increasing trends in average surface and air temperatures. Intensive investigation on climate changes requires fine-grained monitoring and modeling of long-term regional and global climate and weather conditions. The growth of computing power has greatly propelled NASA climate and weather models, such as GEOS-5 and MODEL-E, to achieve good spatial and temporal resolutions. However, these models have seen little improvements in their I/O software stack, resulting in an outcry for commensurate data management capability, including data creation, movement, reanalysis, assimilation, and visualization. In the mean time, there is an ever-widening gap between the speed of CPU processors and that of storage devices. Thus efficient I/O has become a very challenging issue for NASA's climate and weather models. In this project, we propose to design and develop an elastic parallel I/O (EPIO) framework for NASA computational climate and weather models. The main theme of EPIO is to integrate proven I/O technologies, ADIOS and AsyncIO, and design a set of extended APIs that can enhance the existing I/O practices in NASA models. To this aim, we propose the following research activities. First, we will investigate I/O requirements of NASA models such as GEOS-5, MODEL-E, and GCE. Accordingly we will design and develop EPIO as a user-friendly, non-invasive I/O infrastructure that enables NASA models with efficient I/O on NASA computing facilities. Second, through EPIO, we will support NASA models with advanced I/O techniques such as data staging, binary packed format, and workflow coupling for efficient post-processing such as data reanalysis, assimilation, and visualization on Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) leadership facilities. Third, to prepare NASA models for future systems, we will design and develop proof-of-concept I/O techniques. These include topology-aware I/O client selection on highly hierarchical interconnection networks, balanced data distribution through space filing curves, and multi-level data deduplication to reduce network bandwidth consumptions and storage footprints. Last but not least, we will have a comprehensive assessment and evaluation plan to validate EPIO, and enable its smooth adoption by NASA climate models for very high-resolution simulations on NASA and ORNL computer systems. This project will have great significance for NASA's climate and weather predictions. The primary outcome from the proposed EPIO framework will be an I/O middleware library that is equipped with user-friendly, non-invasive APIs, and can seamlessly transform NASA climate and weather models for optimal I/O performance on NASA and ORNL facilities. Together, these software facilities can parallelize I/O inputs and outputs in NASA models, streamline data movement among workflows of NASA climate simulation, data assimilation, and data visualization systems, thereby significantly enhancing spatial and temporal resolutions of climate and weather predictions. Climatologists will be able to exploit recent architectural advances in computers without being overwhelmed by hardware and software intricacies. Upon completion of this project, the increased I/O efficiency will result in fast turnaround time (i.e., more executions completed per hour), making better use of the existing computing and I/O resources. This work will be of interest to all NASA centers deploying high performance computing facilities and running climate and weather models, as well as other organizations such as the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

column17: THE ACADEMY OF AEROSPACE QUALITY (AAQ) SERVES AN INTERNET-BASED FORUM FOR PROVIDING QUALITY ASSURANCE TRAINING TO ACADEMICS INVOLVED IN AEROSPACE RESEARCH, TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT, AND PAYLOAD DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT. THE AAQ CURRICULUM INCLUDES MODULES FOR ALL ASPECTS OF QUALITY ASSURANCE NECESSARY TO ENSURE PROJECT SUCCESS AND PROVIDES A VIRTUAL COMMUNITY FOR NETWORKING AND SHARING OF LESSONS-LEARNED AMONG LIKE-MINDED SCHOLARS. CURRENT YEAR OBJECTIVES ARE TO IMPROVE THE USER INTERFACE, IMPROVE THE QUIZ MODULE, ADD USER-SPECIFIC LOGIN ACCOUNTS, CONTINUE TO COMPLETE CURRICULUM MODULES, AND BEGIN TO ADD LESSONS LEARNED CASE STUDIES.

column9: Educational - 1862 Land Grant College, Educational Institution, Other Not For Profit Organization, State Controlled Institution of Higher Learning
column17: THE ORIGINAL PROPOSED RESEARCH AIMS TO COMPREHENSIVELY INVESTIGATE HOW CHORUS WAVES ARISE IN THE MAGNETOSPHERE FROM LINEAR PLASMA INSTABILITY AND NONLINEAR WAVE GROWTH, AS WELL AS HOW THE CONSEQUENT (QUASI-LINEAR AND NONLINEAR) ELECTRON SCATTERING BY CHORUS WAVES CONTRIBUTES TO ENERGY GAIN AND SCATTERING LOSS OF RELATIVISTIC ELECTRONS IN THE RADIATION BELTS. THE WORK HAS BEEN ORGANIZED INTO FOUR DISTINCT TASKS: 1) WE WILL USE GEOSYNCHRONOUS OBSERVATIONS FROM LOS ALAMOS PLASMA INSTRUMENTS AND THE KINETIC RING CURRENT-ATMOSPHERIC INTERACTIONS MODEL (RAM), THROUGH LINEAR KINETIC INSTABILITY ANALYSIS, TO GAIN INSIGHT INTO THE ELECTRON VELOCITY DISTRIBUTIONS LEADING TO THE EXCITATION OF CHORUS; 2) USING SUCH DISTRIBUTIONS, WE WILL USE PIC SIMULATIONS TO GENERATE ENHANCED CHORUS WAVES AND DETERMINE HOW THERMAL AND SUPRATHERMAL ELECTRONS ARE SCATTERED; 3) WE WILL USE TEST-PARTICLE COMPUTATIONS TO CALCULATE HOW ENHANCED CHORUS WAVES PITCH-ANGLE SCATTER AND ACCELERATE RELATIVISTIC ELECTRONS; 4) THE CALCULATED PARTICLE TRANSPORT COEFFICIENTS WILL BE FED BACK INTO THE RAM MODEL TO IMPROVE THE REPRESENTATIONS OF GLOBAL ELECTRON TRANSPORT IN THAT MODEL.

column9: Educational - 1862 Land Grant College, Educational Institution, Other Not For Profit Organization, State Controlled Institution of Higher Learning
column17: UNDERSTANDING THE EVOLUTION OF MULTICELLULAR ORGANISMS IS PARAMOUNT IN ELUCIDATING HOW ADVANCED LIFE CAN COME TO EXIST ON A PLANET. IN THE CASE OF EARTH, SEVERAL MULTICELLULAR GROUPS AROSE INDEPENDENTLY, BUT ONLY ANIMALS HAVE EVOLVED TISSUES THAT ALLOW ACTIVE, RAPID MOVEMENT AND FAST INTERCELLULAR COMMUNICATION. IN ORDER TO DISCERN HOW THESE FEATURES AROSE, WE MUST FIRST UNRAVEL THE EVOLUTIONARY RELATIONSHIPS AMONG THE EARLIEST ANIMAL GROUPS AND IDENTIFY GENETIC MECHANISMS RESPONSIBLE FOR CREATING ADVANCED SYSTEMS SUCH AS NERVOUS AND MUSCULE TISSUE. A CANDIDATE GENE APPROACH HAS PROVIDED RESEARCHERS SOME INSIGHT AS TO IMPORTANT GENES THAT MAY HAVE BEEN INITIALLY IMPORTANT IN SHAPING NERVOUS AND MUSCULAR SYSTEMS, BUT OUR KNOWLEDGE IS LIMITED TO A FEW MODEL ANIMALS SPECIES. MOREOVER, RECENT STUDIES HAVE CHALLENGED THE LONG HELD VIEW THAT SPONGES, WHICH LACK NERVES AND MUSCLES, ARE THE BASAL-MOST ANIMAL GROUP. IN CONTRAST, PHYLOGENOMIC ANALYSES SUGGEST THAT CTENOPHORES, OR COMB JELLIES, MAY BE BASAL-MOST. THESE CONTRASTING HYPOTHESES HAVE RADICALLY DIFFERENT IMPLICATIONS FOR UNDERSTANDING WHICH ATTRIBUTES WERE PRESENT IN EARLY ANIMAL LINEAGES AND RAISE THE POSSIBILITY THAT NERVOUS SYSTEMS AND MUSCLES MAY HAVE INDEPENDENTLY EVOLVED TWICE IN METAZOANS. WITHIN  EXOBIOLOGY AND EVOLUTIONARY BIOLOGY,  NASA HAS TAKEN PARTICULAR INTEREST IN THE EVOLUTION OF ADVANCED LIFE. EXPLORING HOW MULTICELLULAR LIFE ON EARTH EVOLVED COMPLEX FEATURES SUCH AS NERVES AND MUSCLE WILL INFORM UNDERSTANDING OF CONDITIONS NEEDED FOR ADVANCED LIFE TO EVOLVE ELSEWHERE IN THE UNIVERSE. HEREIN WE FOCUS ON ANIMALS BECAUSE DUE TO THEIR NERVOUS SYSTEMS THEY POSSESS INTELLIGENCE AND DUE TO THEIR MUSCULAR SYSTEM THEY HAVE THE ABILITY TO ACTIVELY CONTROL THEIR DISPERSAL. WE PROPOSE TO USE A GENOMIC APPROACH TO UNDERSTAND THE ORIGINS AND EARLY HISTORY OF ANIMALS. WE WILL FOCUS ON EXANT ANIMAL LINEAGES THAT BRANCHED OFF NEAR THE BASE OF THE ANIMAL TREE. THESE INCLUDE SPONGES, CNIDARIANS (ANEMONES AND JELLIES), CTENOPHORES (COMB JELLIES), AND PLACOZOANS (MICROSCOPIC, SPONGE-LIKE ANIMALS). MORE SPECIFICALLY, WE PROPOSE TO SEQUENCE AT LEAST 12 GENOMES AND 30 TRANSCRIPTOMES OF BASAL ANIMAL GROUPS. BY COLLECTING AND ANALYZING SUCH DATA FROM STRATEGICALLY CHOSEN TAXA, WE WILL ADDRESS THREE BASIC QUESTIONS ABOUT EARLY ANIMAL LINEAGES: 1) WHAT ARE THE EVOLUTIONARY RELATIONSHIPS AMONG THE MAJOR GROUPS? 2)HOW HAVE GENETIC MECHANISMS OF NERVOUS AND MUSCLE SYSTEMS EVOLVED? AND 3) DO THE THE BASAL ANIMAL LINEAGES HAVE UNIQUE GENE SYSTEMS UNKNOWN OR ABSENT IN BILATERIANS? TO THIS END, WE HAVE ASSEMBLED A COLLABORATIVE TEAM BETWEEN KEN HALANYCH S LAB, WHICH HAS LONG STANDING INTERESTS IN DEEP ANIMAL EVOLUTION, AND LEONID MOROZ S LAB, WHICH IS EXAMINING DIVERSITY AND FUNCTIONS OF THE NERVOUS SYSTEM ACROSS ANIMALS. BOTH LABS UTILIZE NEXT-GENERATION SEQUENCING APPROACHES AND CONTINUE TO DEVELOP BIOINFORMATIC EXPERTISE. ADDITIONALLY, THE RESOURCES GENERATED HEREIN WILL GREATLY AUGMENT SEVERAL DIFFERENT LINES OF BIOLOGICAL RESEARCH BY PROVIDING NEEDED GENOMIC DATA FOR SEVERAL KEY LINEAGES OF BASAL ANIMALS.

column9: Educational - 1862 Land Grant College, Educational Institution, Other Not For Profit Organization, State Controlled Institution of Higher Learning
column17: THE SPACE SHUTTLE REUSABLE SOLID ROCKET MOTOR STATIC TESTS HAVE EXHIBITED DIFFERENCES BETWEEN MEASURED FIRST LONGITUDINAL MODE PRESSURE OSCILLATIONS NEAR THE END OF BURN WHEN COMPARED TO ALMOST ALL OF THE FLIGHT DATA. ONE POSSIBILITY FOR THIS IS THAT STRUCTURAL/ACOUSTIC COUPLING OCCURS BETWEEN THE MOTOR TEST STAND AND THE MOTOR DURING THIS TIME PERIOD. THE COMPLEXITY OF THE STATIC TEST ENVIRONMENT IS TOO COMPLEX TO PERMIT VERIFICATION OF THIS DYNAMIC COUPLING WITH EXISTING MODELS AND DATA. AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE DIFFERENCES BETWEEN STATIC TEST MEASUREMENTS AND FLIGHT DATA FOR THESE PRESSURE OSCILLATIONS WOULD IMPROVE NASA''S CAPABILITY TO UNDERSTAND AND MODEL THE RSMRMV/ADVANCED BOOSTER DYNAMIC RESPONSE. THE WORK WOULD AID IN THE DETERMINATION OF THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THE EFFECTS OF THE DYNAMIC COUPLING AND DEPENDING ON THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THESE EFFECTS PROVIDE A BASIS FOR FURTHER ANALYSIS AND MODEL DEVELOPMENT.

column9: Educational - 1862 Land Grant College, Educational Institution, Other Not For Profit Organization, State Controlled Institution of Higher Learning
column17: THIS PROPOSAL SUGGESTS THE USE OF OPTIMIZATION TO EXPLORE THE BENEFITS OF USING SUB-COOLED LIQUID PROPANE AS A PRIMARY PROPELLANT FOR MULTIPLE STAGE ROCKET POWERED LAUNCH VEHICLES. SUBCOOLED PROPANE APPEARS TO OFFER SOME ADVANTAGES OVER MORE TRADITIONAL FUELS SUCH AS RP-1 AND LIQUID HYDROGEN BOTH FROM A PERFORMANCE PERSPECTIVE AND FROM A LOGISTICS PERSPECTIVE. FROM A PERFORMANCE PERSPECTIVE, SUB-COOLED PROPANE HAS THE HIGHEST DENSITY SPECIFIC IMPULSE OF ANY HYDROCARBON WHEN PAIRED WITH LOX. FROM A LOGISTICS PERSPECTIVE, SUB-COOLED PROPANE IS ATTRACTIVE BECAUSE IT CAN BE STORED AT LOX TEMPERATURES AND IS THUS VIABLE AS A FUEL IN A SINGLE TANK CONFIGURATION FOR A GIVEN STAGE IN WHICH THE FUEL AND OXIDIZER ARE SEPARATED BY A BAFFLE. THE IMPACT OF SUB-COOLED PROPANE ON VEHICLE ARCHITECTURE AND PAYLOAD WILL BE EXPLORED AND COMPARED WITH THE PERFORMANCE OF OPTIMIZED VEHICLES USING MORE TRADITIONAL FUELS INCLUDING HYDROGEN AND RP-1 . OPTIMIZATION IS_ USED TO COMPARE ULTIMATE ACHIEVABLE PERFORMANCE FOR COMPETING PROPELLANT COMBINATIONS AND WILL PROVIDE OPTIMAL PRELIMINARY DESIGN LEVEL ARCHITECTURES FOR SUB-COOLED PROPANE FUELED VEHICLES.

column17: THE ACADEMY OF AEROSPACE QUALITY (AAQ) SERVES AS AN INTERNET-BASED FORUM FOR PROVIDING QUALITY ASSURANCE TRAINING TO ACADEMICS INVOLVED IN AEROSPACE RESEARCH, TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT, AND PAYLOAD DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT. THE AAQ CURRICULUM INCLUDES MODULES FOR ALL ASPECTS OF QUALITY ASSURANCE NECESSARY TO ENSURE PROJECT SUCCESS AND PROVIDES A VIRTUAL COMMUNITY FOR NETWORKING AND SHARING OF LESSONS-LEARNED AMONG LIKE-MINDED SCHOLARS. CURRENT YEAR OBJECTIVES ARE TO ADD AN INTERACTIVE, ONLINE QUALITY ASSURANCE PLAN TEMPLATE APPROPRIATE FOR ACADEMIC TEAMS ENGAGED IN PAYLOAD DEVELOPMENT, CONTINUE TO COMPLETE CURRICULUM MODULES, HOLD A ONE DAY WORKSHOP OF KEY USERS CONSTITUTING A USER STEERING COMMITTEE, CONTINUE TO ADD CASE STUDIES AND LESSONS LEARNED, IMPROVE THE SELF QUIZ MODULES, ASSEMBLE A SMALLBODY OF EXPERT USERS AS AN AAQ USER STEERING COMMITTEE, AND IMPROVE THE PEDAGOGICAL ASPECTS OF THE CURRICULUM MODULES

column17: WE PROPOSE A PROGRAM OF COMPUTATIONS OF ATOMIC QUANTITIES NEEDED FOR INTERPRETATIONS OF X-RAY SPECTRA TAKEN WITH THE SXS INSTRUMENT ONT EH ASTRO-H SATELLITE IN THE 5-10 KEV ENERGY RANGE FOR TRACE ELEMENTW AND PROCESSES NOT YET TREATED IN DETIALS. MOST IMPORTANT ARE THE PHOTOIONIZATION AND PHOTOABSORPTION CROSS SECTIONS FROM TEH K SHELLS OF IONS OF F, NA, P, CL, K, SC, TI, V, CR, MN, CO, CU, AND ZN. THESE WILL UTILIZE THE R-MATRIX TECHNIQUES WHICH WE HAVE ALREADY APPLIED TO MANY IONS OF ASTROPHYSICAL INTEREST. ALL THE RESULTS OF OUR WORK WILL BE MADE FRELY AVAILABLE  AS QUICKLY POSSIBLE AND PUBLISHED IN THE FORM OF ELCTRONIC TABLES AVAILABLE THROUGH OUR DATABASE AND ON-LINE TABLES ASSOCIATED WITH PUBLISHED JOURNAL ARTICLES. DATA WILL ALSO BE INCORPORATED IN THE XSTAR CODE FOR USE IN DIRECT FITTING OF MODELS TO OBSERVED DATA.

column17: IGF::OT::IGF OTHER FUNCTION -   WITH THE RETIRING OF THE SHUTTLE FLEET, UP-MASS AND DOWN-MASS TO ISS ARE AT A PREMIUM. THE SPACE STATION ITSELF HAS A LIMITED LIFECYCLE AS WELL, THUS LONG-TERM AND/OR HIGH-RISK DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS POSE ISSUES FOR SCIENCE ''RETURN ON INVESTMENT'', IF THE TECHNOLOGY CANNOT BE ADEQUATELY MATURED BEFORE THE STATION IS DECOMMISSIONED. THUS INNOVATIVE SYSTEMS AND TECHNOLOGIES THAT MINIMIZE IMPACT ON LIMITING RESOURCES SUCH AS UP-MASS, DOWN-MASS AND CREW TIME, AND CAN DO SO IN THE NEAR- TO MID-TERM, ARE HIGHLY DESIRABLE. ONE SUCH AREA INCLUDES THE VARIOUS RECHARGEABLE BATTERY SYSTEMS ON ISS USED EXTENSIVELY FOR CAMERAS, CAMCORDERS, LAPTOPS, COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS AND OTHER PORTABLE SCIENCE AND DIAGNOSTIC EQUIPMENT.  A COMMON (UNIVERSAL) BATTERY CHARGING SYSTEM FOR ISS, WITH THE FLEXIBILITY TO ACCOMMODATE CURRENT AND FUTURE RECHARGEABLE BATTERY REQUIREMENTS FOR PAYLOADS AND EQUIPMENT, COULD REDUCE THE COST OF USE OF THE ISS FOR PAYLOAD DEVELOPERS. SUCH A SYSTEM WOULD NOT ONLY SIMPLIFY THE SAFETY AND INTEGRATION PROCESS FOR BATTERY-OPERATED ISS APPLICATIONS, BUT ALSO REDUCE UP-MASS BY MAKING USE OF EXISTING ISS RESOURCES. IN ITS SBIR PHASE I PROGRAM, AURORA FLIGHT SCIENCES LAID THE GROUNDWORK FOR SUCH A SYSTEM, BASED ON THE NEEDS OF CURRENT AND PLANNED ISS BATTERY SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS. THE RESULTS OF THE STUDY INDICATE THAT A UNIVERSAL RECHARGEABLE BATTERY SYSTEM IS FEASIBLE AND COULD SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCE UP-MASS AND CREW-TIME TO SUPPORT CURRENT AND FUTURE ISS PROGRAMS. EXPANDING ON THE FEASIBILITY STUDY PERFORMED IN PHASE I, AURORA WILL DELIVER A PROTOFLIGHT CHARGER SYSTEM AND SUPPORTING DOCUMENTATION AT THE CONCLUSION OF PHASE II. THE PROPOSED SYSTEM WILL BE FULLY DEVELOPED IN COMPLIANCE WITH NASA SAFETY AND INTEGRATION CRITERIA WITHIN THE 2-YEAR SBIR PHASE II TIMEFRAME, FACILITATING PROCUREMENT OF FLIGHT AND GROUND SUPPORT HARDWARE BY NASA IN A POTENTIAL PHASE III PROGRAM.

column17: IGF::OT::IGF TO ADVANCE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF EXERCISE ACTIVITIES PERFORMED TO COUNTERACT BONE AND MUSCLE DETERIORATION UNDER MICROGRAVITY CONDITIONS, AURORA FLIGHT SCIENCES AND THE MASSACHUSETTS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY PROPOSE TO DEVELOP A SELF-CONTAINED, ENHANCED DYNAMIC LOAD SENSOR THAT CAN BE INTEGRATED INTO THE EXISTING EXERCISE EQUIPMENT ONBOARD THE INTERNATIONAL SPACE STATION. THESE SENSORS WILL ALLOW THE COLLECTION OF CREWMEMBER BIOMECHANICAL WHILE THEY ARE EXERCISING ON-ORBIT. THESE DATA CAN BE USED TO VALIDATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE COUNTERMEASURES AND IMPROVE THEIR IMPACT TO MITIGATE BONE AND MUSCLE LOSS DURING LONG DURATION SPACEFLIGHT MISSIONS.

column9: , Small Business Innovative Research, Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization, Manufacturer Of Goods
column17: IGF::OT::IGF THE AVAILABILITY OF AN AIR VEHICLE TO PERFORM MISSIONS OR GENERATE SORTIES IS NEGATIVELY IMPACTED BY TIME SPENT ON THE GROUND DUE TO SCHEDULED SERVICING AND MAINTENANCE. CONDITION BASED MAINTENANCE (CBM) HELPS MAXIMIZE THE AVAILABILITY OF AIR ASSETS BY SERVICING THE AIR VEHICLE BASED ON ACTUAL CONDITION AS OPPOSED TO A FIXED NUMBER OF OPERATING HOURS. PROGNOSTICS AND HEALTH MANAGEMENT (PHM) ENABLES IMPROVED CBM ON AIR VEHICLES BY COMPARING  IN-SITU SENSOR DATA TO PROGNOSTIC MODELS OF COMPONENTS AND SUBSYSTEMS TO PREDICT WEAR AS IT OCCURS. INTEGRATION OF THESE PHM SYSTEMS WITH AN AUTONOMIC LOGISTICS INFRASTRUCTURE CAN LEAD TO EVEN GREATER INCREASES IN SORTIE GENERATION RATES AND DECREASES IN MAINTENANCE COST AND LOGISTICS BURDEN BY ELIMINATING UNNECESSARY PREVENTATIVE MAINTENANCE AS WELL AS IDENTIFYING FAILURES OCCURRING OUTSIDE THE NORMAL SCHEDULED MAINTENANCE CYCLE. AURORA\'S INNOVATIVE APPROACH UTILIZES INFORMATION FROM EXISTING SENSORS (I.E., DOES NOT REQUIRE ADDITIONAL SENSORS ADDED TO THE VEHICLE, HENCE, \'SENSOR-FREE\') TO DETERMINE PHM.CURRENT IMPLEMENTATION OF PHM IS FOCUSED ON NEW DESIGNS OF MANNED AIRCRAFT TO ALLOW CO-DEVELOPMENT OF THE PHM SYSTEM AND ITS SPECIFIC  SENSORS. UNMANNED AERIAL SYSTEMS (UAS) HAVE SENSORS AND SUBSYSTEMS ALREADY INSTALLED THAT CAN PROVIDE THE CAPABILITY FOR A PHM RETROFIT ON IN-FLEET SYSTEMS. UAV SPECIFIC SUBSYSTEMS, SUCH AS THE AUTOPILOT, ALSO PROVIDE THE OPPORTUNITY FOR NEW PHM CAPABILITIES BEYOND THOSE CONSIDERED IN MANNED AIRCRAFT. AURORA PROPOSES THE INTEGRATED VEHICLE HEALTH MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (IVHMS). AURORA\'S IVHMS WILL COMPARE MODELS OF THE AIRCRAFT IN DIFFERENT CONFIGURATIONS TO AN ESTIMATE OF THE CURRENT STATE OF THE AIRCRAFT IN ORDER TO GENERATE A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE REAL-TIME OPERATING CONDITION OF THE VEHICLE AND ITS CONSTITUENT COMPONENTS. THE IVHMS USES THESE CAPABILITIES TO GENERATE A VEHICLE-WIDE IDENTIFICATION OF SYSTEMS IN ORDER TO DETECT FAULTS AS THEY INFLUENCE OVERALL PERFORMANCE.

column9: , Small Business Innovative Research, Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization, Manufacturer Of Goods
column17: IGF::OT::IGF AURORA WILL DEVELOP A NOVEL COMPOSITE SANDWICH STRUCTURE THAT IS CAPABLE OF PROVIDING A COUPLED BENDING-TORSIONAL STIFFNESS WITH NONLINEAR ELASTIC EFFECTS, CAPABLE OF ACHIEVING A TAILORED AEROELASTIC RESPONSE OVER A WIDE RANGE OF FLIGHT CONDITIONS. SUCH A STRUCTURE WILL MAKE USE OF AN ADDITIVE MANUFACTURED CORE WITH HIGHLY TAILORED AND OPTIMIZED CELLULAR SUBSTRUCTURE. THE CELLULAR STRUCTURE WILL BE FUNCTIONALLY GRADED IN THE SPANWISE AND CHORDWISE DIRECTIONS TO PROVIDE A COUPLED BENDING-TORSIONAL STIFFNESS RESPONSE. FIBER REINFORCED COMPOSITE FACESHEETS WILL PROVIDE STRENGTH. UTILIZING THE CORE STRUCTURE TO COUPLE THE BENDING-TORSIONAL STIFFNESS OF THE COMPOSITE MAY ALLOW THE COMPOSITE TO REMAIN BALANCED AND SYMMETRIC, THUS AVOIDING INDUCED STRESSES AND/OR WARPING DURING MANUFACTURING.

column9: , Small Business ONLY - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization, Manufacturer Of Goods
column17: IGF::OT::IGF  AURORA PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A VISION-BASED SUBSYSTEM FOR INCORPORATION ONTO MARS VEHICLES IN THE AIR (VTOL) AND ON THE GROUND. NOAMAD WILL BE AN EMBEDDED HARDWARE DEVICE WITH ASSOCIATED FIRMWARE FOR PAYLOADLIMITED UAVS, PERFORMING AUTONOMOUS NAVIGATION, OBSTACLE AVOIDANCE, GUIDANCE USING BIOINSPIRED METHODS, AND COMMUNICATION OF INFORMATION BETWEEN AGENTS WITHIN THE AUTONOMOUS TEAM. NOAMAD WILL TRANSITION UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND METHODS FOR INSECT-INSPIRED, LIGHTWEIGHT, VISION- AND OPTICAL SENSOR-BASED NAVIGATION METHODS INTO A SUBSYSTEM THAT ENABLES EXPANSION OF THE EXPLORATORY CAPABILITY OF THE VEHICLES ON WHICH IT IS INSTALLED. THE SUBSYSTEM WILL PROVIDE (1) LOCALIZATION (WITHOUT A GLOBAL NAVIGATION SYSTEM OR COMPASS) USING OPTIC-FLOW BASED ODOMETRY COMBINED WITH LANDMARK DETECTION, (2) OBSTACLE DETECTION AND AVOIDANCE USING OPTIC FLOW, AND (3) AUTONOMOUS GUIDANCE USING POSITION INFORMATION TOGETHER WITH BIO-INSPIRED BEHAVIORS. TAKEN TOGETHER, THESE FUNCTIONS WILL ALLOW AIR AND GROUND VEHICLES TO WORK TOGETHER TO ACHIEVE PROGRESSIVELY REFINED MAPS OF AN EXPLORATION REGION.

column9: , Small Business Innovative Research, Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization, Manufacturer Of Goods
column17: IGF::OT::IGF  TRADITIONAL HYDRAULIC ACTUATION AND CONTROL SURFACE LAYOUT BOTH LIMIT SPAN WISE CONTROL OF LIFT DISTRIBUTION, AND REQUIRE LARGE VOLUME WITHIN WING CROSS-SECTION, ULTIMATELY REDUCING EFFICIENCY. MOUNTING AND SUPPORT STRUCTURES FOR TRADITIONAL ACTUATORS, ALSO NECESSITATE DRAG-INDUCING PROTRUSIONS IN OTHERWISE IDEALLY SMOOTH AIRFOILS. CONSEQUENTLY, HYDRAULIC SYSTEMS ARE HEAVY AND ENERGY INTENSIVE AS COMPARED TO ELECTROMECHANICAL COUNTERPARTS. COUPLING DISTRIBUTED EMAS WITH NOVEL CONTROLS OPTIMIZING LIFT DISTRIBUTION IN REAL-TIME DURING FLIGHT ALLOWS LIGHTER, THINNER, AND MORE FLEXIBLE WING STRUCTURE. MULTIDISCIPLINARY DESIGN OPTIMIZATION USED TO COUPLE CONTROL FORMULATION FOR ANY POINT IN FLIGHT WITH AEROELASTIC MODEL OF THE WING. PARAMETRIC DISTRIBUTION OF EMAS WILL GUIDE ACTUATOR PLACEMENT AND AID DESIGN AND SIZING OF FLEXIBLE WING SYSTEM THAT MAXIMIZES L/D. AURORA HAS USED BOTH DISTRIBUTED LOCAL FLOW SENSORS AND ON-BOARD FIBER-OPTIC STRAIN SENSORS, WHICH ALONG WITH NOVEL CONTROL ALGORITHMS ALLOW FOR ON-BOARD, NEAR REAL-TIME CONTROL CALCULATIONS TO BE COMPLETED, CREATING ADAPTIVE WING SHAPES, AND OPTIMIZE L/D WITHIN THE FLIGHT ENVELOPE.

column9: , Small Business Innovative Research, Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization, Manufacturer Of Goods
column17: IGF::OT::IGF  NEW MEASUREMENT TECHNOLOGIES ARE REQUIRED TO SUPPORT SCIENCE CAMPAIGNS TO BETTER QUANTIFY RAPID CHANGES IN THE EARTH ATMOSPHERE SYSTEM. A KEY FACTOR IN THIS HEIGHTENED FOCUS ON RISK AND UNCERTAINTY IS THE GROWING RECOGNITION THAT THE CLIMATE IS CHANGING FAR MORE RAPIDLY THAN WAS THOUGHT JUST FIVE YEARS AGO. AURORA FLIGHT SCIENCES AND HARVARD UNIVERSITY PROPOSE TO MINIATURIZE THE HARVARD INTEGRATED CAVITY OUTPUT SPECTROSCOPY (ICOS) INSTRUMENT FOR USE IN THE UNIQUE REEL-DOWN PAYLOAD POD OF THE \STRATOCRUISER\", A PROPOSED PROPULSIVE HIGH-ALTITUDE BALLOON GONDOLA. COMBINING THE PERSISTENCE OF BALLOON PLATFORMS, THE VERTICAL MEASUREMENTS OF SOUNDINGS, AND THE MOBILITY OF AIRCRAFT THE STRATOCRUISER WILL ENABLE NEW UNDERSTANDING OF STRATOSPHERIC PHENOMENON. THE FOCUS OF THE PROPOSED EFFORT WILL BE TO ENHANCE THE STRATOCRUISER REEL-DOWN PAYLOAD CAPABILITY THROUGH SIZE, WEIGHT, AND/OR POWER (SWAP) REDUCTION IN THE DUAL LASER, 50 CM CELL, ICOS INSTRUMENT. THE SOUNDINGS FROM THE STRATOCRUISER ICOS-BASED OBSERVING SYSTEM PROVIDE LABORATORY QUALITY, IN SITU DETECTION OF RADICALS, ISOTOPES, OZONE, REACTIVE INTERMEDIATES, LONG-LIVED TRACERS AND CONDENSED AND VAPOR PHASE H2O AND HDO OVER THE US FOR A PERIOD OF 4-6 WEEKS."

column9: , Small Business Innovative Research, Small Business - Corporate Entity Not Tax Exempt, For Profit Organization, Manufacturer Of Goods
column17: IGF::OT::IGFAURORA FLIGHT SCIENCES AND THE MASSACHUSETTS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY (MIT) PROPOSE TO DEVELOP A STAND-ALONE 6-DOF LOAD SENSING SYSTEM THAT COLLECTS BIOMECHANICAL FORCE AND MOMENT DATA WHILE INTEGRATED WITH THE ADVANCED RESISTIVE EXERCISE DEVICE (ARED) ON THE INTERNATIONAL SPACE STATION BYADAPTING AND ENHANCING PREVIOUSLY FIELD-TESTED SYSTEMS. OUR EDLS-ISS SYSTEM INCLUDES A SEPARATE BASE UNIT TETHERED TO TWO LOW-PROFILE SENSORS, WHICH CAN BE NON-INVASIVELY MOUNTED ON THE SURFACE OF THE ARED TO SERVE AS NEW FOOTPLATES. THE EDLS-ISS IS BEING DEVELOPED FOR TWO REASONS:- OPERATIONAL. FORCE PLATES ON THE ARED WILL ALLOW CREWMEMBERS TO VERIFY LOADING, AND TO RECORD FORCES. THIS DEVICE PROVIDES A SIMPLE, NON-INVASIVE SOLUTION THAT MEASURES FOOT FORCES AND DISPLAYS THIS TO THE ASTRONAUT.- RESEARCH. KINEMATIC EXPERIMENTS ON THE ARED   FOR EXAMPLE, CHARACTERIZING LIMB SEGMENT RELATIVEMOTIONS DURING A SQUAT   REQUIRE CORRESPONDING FORCE AND MOMENT MEASUREMENTS. OUR EDLS-ISS SYSTEM PROVIDES THREE-AXIS FORCE AND THREE-AXIS MOMENT MEASUREMENTS FOR SUCH EXPERIMENTS. BY PROVIDING A SHORT-TERM OPERATIONAL SOLUTION AND A SUSTAINABLE LONG-TERM RESEARCH SOLUTION, ELDSISSIS AN IMPORTANT TOOL FOR THE SPACEFLIGHT COMMUNITY.DURING PHASE I, WE IMPROVED THE DESIGN OF THE EXISTING 6-DOF MICROGRAVITY INVESTIGATION OF CREW REACTIONS IN 0-G (MICR0-G) ADAPT SENSOR MODULE, PREVIOUSLY DEVELOPED BY AURORA AND MIT. THESE IMPROVEMENTS OPTIMIZED THE SENSOR FOR USE ON THE ARED: DECREASING THE OVERALL HEIGHT OF THE SENSORS AND SEPARATING THE ELECTRONICS INTO AN OFF-BOARD \BASE UNIT\", INCREASING THE FOOTPRINT SIZE TO COVER MOST OF THE SURFACE OF THE ARED PLATFORM, UPDATING THE HARD DRIVE AND ELECTRONICS, PROVIDING A REAL-TIMEUSER-FEEDBACK DISPLAY, AND DEVELOPING ARED MOUNTING OPTIONS. THE ANTICIPATED RESULT OF OUR PHASE IIEFFORT WILL BE THREE COMPLETE EDLS-ISS SYSTEMS, EACH OF WHICH INCLUDES A BASE UNIT AND TWO SENSOR UNITS. TWO SYSTEMS WILL BE FLIGHT-QUALIFIED."
